corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

unittitle.value: American Labor Party Minutes and Proceedings

abstract.value: The American Labor Party was a short-lived group founded in 1922. The collection contains convention proceedings and minutes, which have been microfilmed. Patrons must use microfilm copy (R-7862)

p.value: Published citations should take the following form: <lb/><lb/>Identification of item, date; Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number; <lb/>Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives <lb/>Elmer Holmes Bobst Library <lb/>70 Washington Square South <lb/>New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.
Transferred from the Rand School Archives, 1963. The accession number associated with this collection is 1963.002.

The American Labor Party (ALP), was a short lived group, organized along lines of British Labour Party, that was founded in New York City in 1922 by delegates from Socialist Party, Farmer Labor Party, Workmen's Circle, Poale Zion, and 82 labor organizations.

This collection contains minutes of the Party's three conventions (1922-1923), Executive Committee minutes (1922-1924), and General Campaign Committee minutes (1922). Prominent persons active in the ALP include: Joseph D. Cannon, Edward F. Cassidy, Nathan Fine, Julius Gerber, Marie B. MacDonald, James Oneal, and A.I. Shiplacoff.

subject.value: Working class -- United States -- Political activity.
